messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Jingasa ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Rich- YAY! SUCCESS! Yes, that s a jingasa. As far as stylistic dating goes, I m not entirely sure. Most of the sengoku era jingasa I ve seen in illustrations
messages.messageBody:
Rich-

YAY! SUCCESS!

Yes, that's a jingasa. As far as stylistic dating
goes, I'm not entirely sure. Most of the sengoku era
jingasa I've seen in illustrations are a little
flatter, and are made of iron, as you would expect of
military headgear. I believe during this time you had
two types: iron jingasa the Ashigaru used as headgear,
and the straw/thatch versions used by the peasantry,
monks, women, etc. During the Edo period is when I
believe you saw a switch to your average samurai
wearing them as headgear, and you see the switch to
lacquered versions.

Of course, I really have no idea. Still looking
though.

Nate

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Jingasa ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Rich-- Not one of thos links worked. Did you try the link I posted, and is that the one you are looking for? There s something messed up with the code. As far
messages.messageBody:
Rich--

Not one of thos links worked. Did you try the link I
posted, and is that the one you are looking for?
There's something messed up with the code.

As far as differences in Jingasa, I'm not too sure--I
believe that there were varying style of jingasa, but
don't know if there was any differences between
regions or eras. I'll see what I can dig up.

Nate
